3E116EF076C446AE8D73C652C41279EC.description: identify inorganic substances that can be found dissolved in water as a result of natural processes and human activities (e.g., hard water contains metal ions)

921BFA30922A4D0591A671506AC27096.description: explain the difference between the concepts of strength and concentration when referring to solutions of acids and bases

4EC5B56F5FC349FBB8E85F7DAF507AF8.description: identify the gas emissions that are the major contributors to acid precipitation, and explain the steps in the formation of acid rain

F120E7AFDB9847E89D116EFC835AA38B.description: explain the difference between strong and weak acids, and between strong and weak bases, in terms of degree of ionization

EABACC08428D423CBB32CE6B90B388C6.description: state and explain the Arrhenius definition of acids and bases

C863DEC43E0F4A30805BB9E034FE835D.description: identify gases and particulates that are commonly found in the atmosphere, and explain how they affect air quality (e.g., greenhouse gases, tropospheric and stratospheric ozone, carbon monoxide, chlorofluorocarbons, soot)

7C42D90E5FD142EA93154BB04751D8A0.description: identify major and minor chemical components of Earth's atmosphere

C8FFF7B2E01A41BF80C28152DEDEFBA2.description: conduct an inquiry, using available technology (e.g., probewear) or chemical tests, to detect the presence of inorganic substances in various samples of water

4D216869699D40C2AC4F0ACEB65856A9.description: conduct an acid-base titration to determine the concentration of an acid or a base (e.g., the concentration of acetic acid in vinegar)

31E32D0C41294ED091F3590B866881E5.description: write balanced chemical equations to represent the chemical reactions involved in the neutralization of acids and bases

15297FA125034AFDBB30F2D4390F6459.description: use appropriate terminology related to chemical analysis and chemistry in the environment, including, but not limited to: ozone, hard water, titration, pH, ppm, and ppb

61D3FB7F7F1A4CCF8AA23776547FD3C2.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication

DD69DE2641D749799201325526EE9EDD.description: evaluate the importance of quantitative chemical analysis in assessing air and water quality (e.g., the use of Environment Canada's Air Quality Index to determine when smog advisories need to be issued; systems to monitor the quality of drinking water), and explain how these analyses contribute to environmental awareness and responsibility

59D8535DAD79429AB8D1126088888CA3.description: evaluate, on the basis of research, the effectiveness of government initiatives or regulations (e.g., the Great Lakes Action Plan), and the actions of individuals (e.g., use of public transportation), intended to improve air and water quality, and propose a personal action plan to support these efforts

A38C5F587A3449EC9C6D267A5DE91670.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the importance of government regulations, scientific analyses, and individual actions in improving air and water quality, and propose a personal plan of action to support these efforts;

3A8130F4D95847D29FED3D578670D782.description: explain the concept of a limiting reagent in a chemical reaction, using examples of chemical processes from everyday life (e.g., synthesis of aspirin, synthesis of ammonia)

4D796911571D455583E6EA8F093A11C1.description: explain the concept of molar concentration of a solution, using appropriate units of measure

DC996104EDCD45049E26C9B5BD1C2D8F.description: explain the relationships between the mole concept, the values of coefficients, the number of particles, and the mass of substances in balanced chemical equations

748ED6CE30554AFCAC7107C724E0AD19.description: describe some possible sources of experimental error in an investigation of a chemical reaction, and explain how the errors would affect the percentage yield of products of the reaction

B98DB8E771F74744AE59F20D6BB81B45.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: describe the relationships between Avogadro's number, the mole concept, and the molar mass of any given substance

D2B61C2A2A4B4F5CBBF16422B6BCD432.description: prepare aqueous solutions of given concentrations (e.g., concentrations expressed in grams per litre or moles per litre) by dissolving a solid solute in a solvent or by diluting a concentrated solution (e.g., a stock solution)

657853F438C842479F6490EAA5BC64DA.description: use qualitative observations of a chemical reaction to identify the chemical changes, presence of limiting reagents, and the products occurring in a chemical reaction (e.g., aluminum reacting with copper(II) chloride solution, steel wool reacting with oxygen)

E836133097694B88AF5BF6CD891C059E.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the actual yield, theoretical yield, and percentage yield of the products of a chemical reaction (e.g., a chemical reaction between steel wool and copper(II) sulfate solution), assess the effectiveness of the procedure, and suggest sources of experimental error

33937929669C40C387DA040896F176A6.description: solve problems involving stoichiometric relationships in balanced chemical equations

BF817124A0834AD298D7006B39E3387F.description: solve problems involving relationships between the following variables in a chemical reaction: quantity in moles, number of particles, atomic mass, concentration of solution, and volume of solution

874D6EDE2BA144A2A8947F7091FA1A65.description: convert the quantity of chemicals in simple chemical reactions from number of particles to number of moles and mass, using the mole concept

2F49436EFFBD41758CB635ECC1309CCD.description: calculate the molar mass of simple compounds with the aid of the periodic table

6ECC5539D2844026A7EDE1A0400134A6.description: use appropriate terminology related to stoichiometry, including, but not limited to: molar mass, molar concentration, percentage yield, and Avogadro's number

F86BC56410704DD1B8ADA7F5399D906A.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate chemical compounds and chemical reactions using appropriate techniques of quantitative analysis, and solve related problems;

892EA37A7F184EC6B9841523F1051C88.description: assess, on the basis of research, the importance of quantitative accuracy in the concentration of solutions used for medical purposes or personal care (e.g., cough syrup, intravenous solutions, sunscreen)

D70631651E204704B960D80E8438B324.description: analyse processes in the home, the workplace, or the environmental sector that require an understanding of accurate chemical calculations (e.g., baking according to a recipe; manufacturing items such as fertilizer, paint, pharmaceuticals; testing water quality in a public pool)

3F436F555F5942748E143E47200366F2.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse processes in the home, the workplace, or the environmental sector that use chemical quantities and calculations, and assess the importance of accuracy in chemical calculations;

023A4AD934AF4D248B1492DD7994581C.description: describe the chemical reaction that results in the corrosion of metal

1617FC8798DF42A49187365D3450B703.description: describe the components of a galvanic cell, and explain how each component functions in a redox reaction

20CDDBFE8AEB4C4A9142D4A5F19D0AAF.description: explain the concepts of oxidation and reduction in terms of the chemical changes that occur during redox reactions

0D6FD3E9E9894DA098F02494BE07E85F.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the concepts of oxidation and reduction, and the principles of oxidation-reduction reactions.

97AFBE22F5A34E06A9F723BF1FA51F59.description: design and conduct an inquiry to determine the factors that affect rate of corrosion of a metal (e.g., stress on the metal, contact between two metals, surface oxide, the nature of the electrolyte, the nature of the metal)

AB576B6DC4F94A46826DBD2324383B4A.description: analyse the processes in galvanic cells, and draw labelled diagrams of these cells to show the oxidation or reduction reaction that occurs in each of the half-cells, the direction of electron flow, the location of the electrodes, and the direction of ion movement

439BABEB528748CEA26079A1479A0E95.description: build a galvanic cell and measure its voltage

CC98E495BDD54A7C89777B6D1150EDD9.description: use appropriate terminology related to electrochemistry, including, but not limited to: oxidation, anode, and electrolyte

2FC79BBB42CE4B02AB25E0DA1AE6C796.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication

9FE3F534C14245BF84ED1932D073AC17.description: analyse, on the basis of research, the causes of metal corrosion, and assess the environmental impact of some techniques used to protect metals from corrosion (e.g., rustproofing, painting, cathodic protection, galvanization)

5A0785F949C2431F810B4B073FB7C535.description: analyse, on the basis of research, a technological application that is based on the oxidation-reduction (redox) reaction that occurs in galvanic cells (e.g., in cardiac pacemakers, batteries, electroplating)

F6292131BEB24E0DAF223CAEE146DD55.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: analyse technological applications or processes relating to oxidation-reduction reactions, and assess their impact on the environment;

C88240CECB8D48BF9F63F302AD8E9FB4.description: explain the dangers associated with the use of organic solvents (e.g., dry-cleaning compounds, paint thinners, glue solvents, nail polish remover), and some general precautions related to their use

A1EF134AD1584389AB4A361D94A0D119.description: identify the first ten hydrocarbons of the alkanes, the alkenes, and the alkynes by their names and structural formulae, using International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature for alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes

A99608AA98B04501BA8A9479250934CA.description: explain how the physical properties of a substance affect the processes used to separate organic chemical substances (e.g., distillation of crude oil, distillation of alcohols)

CE74ADA506484E62A4A7440A6754D61F.description: use structural formulae to describe some simple organic chemical reactions (e.g., addition, substitution, combustion)

8F8F5028C386483BA16516D49D66FFFB.description: explain the general properties (e.g., polarity, solubility in water) of molecules that contain oxygen or nitrogen

0CD1825C2DBA4621912A19A695A9602B.description: identify functional group structures that define common classes of organic compounds (e.g., alkenes, alkanes, alkynes, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, amines)

CB5560807BEC4ACCA18EEEA9C4D60188.description: describe the unique characteristics of the carbon atom in terms of covalent bonding

B20FF0982C8242BDA3EE0769214D6BA1.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the structure and the physical and chemical properties of organic compounds.

1E275737D12049148B107F089F71C655.description: predict the nature of a bond (e.g., non-polar covalent or polar covalent), using the electronegativity values of atoms (e.g., H2, Cl2, O2, H2 O, CH4, CH3 OH)

1F641F4850324D66B8C78707422911B6.description: conduct an inquiry to synthesize a common organic compound (e.g., produce an ester, make soap)

E8EB40A2BE634CCABFD624580855733F.description: conduct an inquiry to identify some of the products of the combustion of a hydrocarbon and an alcohol

2291C04F654340CE9BB45D85BB3A73A0.description: conduct an inquiry to demonstrate separation of a mixture of liquids by distillation

39AD9585D4CC48F4A2997644427A01B7.description: conduct an inquiry to determine the physical and chemical properties of some common organic compounds (e.g., solubility [in polar and non-polar solvents], conductivity, odour, combustibility)

196AFF5B28924D049C01A4C4889D0636.description: build molecular models of, and create structural formulae for, some simple organic molecules (e.g., methane, butane, ethyne)

BCC0533C88DB4FC1B0AB0F5EE69C94CB.description: draw Lewis structures to represent the covalent bonds in some simple organic molecules (e.g., CH4 )

D507B93C77EE40EE8B18978330BFC01E.description: use appropriate terminology related to organic chemistry, including, but not limited to: electronegativity, covalent bond, and functional group

78ED80D72E0F47C6B5806DF9C2074A26.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate the physical and chemical properties of organic compounds, and analyse some common organic chemical reactions;

B020B06310CC4D189812C242F8BACEAA.description: research a useful product made from one or more organic substances (e.g., CDs, made from crude oil), and assess the environmental impact of the production, use, and disposal of the product

944672A6C2CC4DE2B95B2E0D1C80C770.description: identify various materials and products used in everyday life that are made from organic compounds (e.g., synthetic fabrics, drugs, pesticides, cosmetics, organic solvents, car parts, artificial hearts), and assess the benefits of those products for society, as well as the health hazards they pose

8DB62EB761E345B1BB107A36EBB85156.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the impact on society, human health, and the environment of products made using organic compounds;

89BF784BDB7A4ED4A5137C464BFC9215.description: relate observations from investigations using flame tests and emission spectra to the concept of quanta of energy proposed by Neils Bohr

5E8ADBBDF5684EAA927035DD453A733A.description: explain basic procedures used in qualitative analysis of elements and compounds, including flame tests, precipitation reactions, and the observation of emission spectra

B6D9F00673484017AF7A68E499A051B6.description: describe various types of chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, single displacement, and double displacement reactions

0184B906554041ABA54F2A591F3F8E6E.description: explain the relationship between the atomic number and the mass number of an element, and the difference between isotopes and radioisotopes of an element

2F9A34431793459CBDFB437999437DE1.description: Understanding Basic Concepts: demonstrate an understanding of the basic principles of qualitative analysis of matter.

131AFF8D0ED146869FDA5DDEE115A556.description: use a table of solubility rules to predict if a precipitate will form in a given chemical reaction, and identify the precipitate formed

79735F5C24BD4C1F932C34A6C8B7AD1B.description: identify an unknown gas sample (e.g., hydrogen, helium, neon) by observing its emission spectrum and comparing it to the spectra of known gases

EDFA6CCCC9DA4C759BFE01D3E42B0265.description: conduct qualitative analyses of an unknown sample (e.g., a household or workplace chemical), using a flow chart and experimental procedures, including flame tests and precipitation reactions, to determine the presence of metal ions

12B5EDD1B8DF4269BB08BDF049412847.description: investigate precipitation reactions and flame tests, using qualitative analysis instruments, equipment, and techniques (e.g., gas discharge tubes, high-voltage electrical sources, spectroscope, centrifuge)

84CA92693108406CB5AA0DDFA12D6700.description: use a table of solubility rules to write chemical equations for double displacement reactions and to write balanced net ionic equations for chemical reactions

B8F696871DFB4643AF37EF2D92AA7D14.description: use appropriate terminology related to qualitative analysis of matter, including, but not limited to: double displacement, precipitate, and energy level

D2B0EEE200244D99926C8BEB56B46A86.description: Developing Skills of Investigation and Communication: investigate matter, using various methods of qualitative analysis;

1853D25B53F043A89E59FECF3AA8D360.description: analyse, on the basis of research, applications of qualitative analysis of matter in various fields of endeavour (e.g., in law enforcement to detect drugs or identify counterfeit money; in the manufacture of food products)

6356D8B6AA09442CBF7855CC1EED50A1.description: evaluate the risks and benefits to the environment of some commonly used chemical substances (e.g., substances used in fireworks, fire extinguishers, "green" cleaning products)

A20C321F1E9A47439F6E3758EC3B1EF0.description: Relating Science to Technology, Society, and the Environment: evaluate the effects of chemical substances on the environment, and analyse practical applications of qualitative analysis of matter;

8CAB6966B85A448A938569CD6DDD6A17.description: describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians (e.g., Jed Harrison, Louis Slotin, Paul Kebarle, James Robert Bolton, Brian Evans Conway, Lee Wilson), to the fields under study

CDFD0E2A7D194B35AE419C0260078907.description: identify and describe a variety of careers related to the fields of science under study (e.g., environmental technologist, pharmacy technician, electroplating technician, green building or renewable energy technician, veterinary technician, biochemical technologist) and the education and training necessary for these careers

31E639B530A94DF1BBC14B336C3F2D1D.description: Career Exploration: identify and describe careers related to the fields of science under study, and describe the contributions of scientists, including Canadians, to those fields.

200FB288283E42018DE9864070021ACD.description: express the results of any calculations involving data accurately and precisely, to the appropriate number of decimal places or significant figures

F941DD771325496DA4774AAFC8AA88E7.description: use appropriate numeric, symbolic, and graphic modes of representation (e.g., represent ionic and molecular compounds by their accepted formulae and names), and appropriate units of measurement (e.g., SI and imperial units)

8043420ED8AE4C01AA9878F25FE903C8.description: communicate ideas, plans, procedures, results, and conclusions orally, in writing, and/or in electronic presentations, using appropriate language and a variety of formats (e.g., data tables, laboratory reports, presentations, debates, simulations, models)

CC61672E8D964F45ADC6DB5B4621A51C.description: draw conclusions based on inquiry results and research findings, and justify their conclusions with reference to scientific knowledge

CA32BBB4DA8A460B8A229564D28E474F.description: analyse the information gathered from research sources for logic, accuracy, reliability, adequacy, and bias

7C8DB5D53B504C6EA36AA645B972BF65.description: synthesize, analyse, interpret, and evaluate qualitative and/or quantitative data; solve problems involving quantitative data; determine whether the evidence supports or refutes the initial prediction or hypothesis and whether it is consistent with scientific theory; identify sources of bias and/or error; and suggest improvements to the inquiry to reduce the likelihood of error

B97A76AD67554706B2554266B215FB18.description: select, organize, and record relevant information on research topics from a variety of appropriate sources, including electronic, print, and/or human sources, using suitable formats and an accepted form of academic documentation

7B6A11D4AED7458685ECEB75AAFB55AF.description: compile accurate data from laboratory and other sources, and organize and record the data, using appropriate formats, including tables, flow charts, graphs, and/or diagrams

B4085F9032DD4C45B0E6012D81A5B1A3.description: conduct inquiries, controlling relevant variables, adapting or extending procedures as required, and using appropriate materials and equipment safely, accurately, and effectively, to collect observations and data

A95BF489A9584B44AAC78FAE12F8E2C3.description: apply knowledge and understanding of safe laboratory practices and procedures when planning investigations by correctly interpreting Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) symbols; by using appropriate techniques for handling and storing laboratory equipment and materials and disposing of laboratory materials (e.g., safely disposing of organic solutions); and by using appropriate personal protection (e.g., wearing safety goggles)

3E32F1DD3D6E40FCA97199F5D13B0A3F.description: identify and locate a variety of print and electronic sources that enable them to address research topics fully and appropriately

98D57473DFCB4BE3BF354B0BADC9798D.description: select appropriate instruments (e.g., spectroscope, centrifuge, burettes, meters) and materials (e.g., acid/base indicators, solubility tables, galvanic cells), and identify appropriate methods, techniques, and procedures, for each inquiry

79EF072CA56D458491273139944FB9DE.description: formulate relevant scientific questions about observed relationships, ideas, problems, or issues, make informed predictions, and/or formulate educated hypotheses to focus inquiries or research

75651ED1340944BEAEB4D22148CB5A5B.description: Scientific Investigation Skills: demonstrate scientific investigation skills (related to both inquiry and research) in the four areas of skills (initiating and planning, performing and recording, analysing and interpreting, and communicating);

EDD2662B0ECC4D31A7E61A810346C1E8.description: Scientific Investigation Skills and Career Exploration
